Словаци у Србији / Slovaci u Srbiju
Slováci v Srbsku |image = |population = '''52,750''' (2011) |region1 = {{flag|Vojvodina}} |pop1 = 50,321 |ref1 = |region2 = |pop2 = |ref2 = |region3 = |pop3 = |ref3 = |region4 = |pop4 = |ref4 = |languages = [[Slovak language|Slovak]] and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] |religions = [[Lutheranism]] |related = |footnotes = }} According to the 2011 census, '''Slovaks''' ({{lang-sr|Словаци/Slovaci}}) in Serbia number 52,750, constituting 0.7% of the country's population.http://popis2011.stat.rs/?lang=en They mainly live in [[Vojvodina]] (50,321), where they constitute the third largest ethnic group after [[Serbs]] and [[Hungarians in Serbia|Hungarians]]. Like other ethnic Slovaks, they speak the [[Slovak language]], but most of them are [[Protestant]] ([[Evangelical Church of the Augsburg Confession in Slovakia|Evangelical-Augsburg Church]], a [[Lutheran]] [[Protestant]] denomination) by faith and not [[Roman Catholic]] like most Slovaks in Slovakia. ==Demographics== [[Image:Vojvodina-Ethnic-2011-op.GIF|thumb|250px|Slovaks in Vojvodina according to the 2011 census (municipality data)]] [[Image:Vojvodina west east slavs.png|thumb|250px|Slovak settlements in Vojvodina (2002 census)]] Most Slovaks live in [[Kovačica (town)|Kovačica]] (8,497 Slovaks) and [[Bački Petrovac]] (5,773 Slovaks). There are two municipalities in Vojvodina with absolute or relative Slovak majorities: [[Bački Petrovac]] (with 66.4% Slovaks) and [[Kovačica (town)|Kovačica]] (with 41% Slovaks). The towns of [[Kovačica (town)|Kovačica]] and [[Bački Petrovac]] are the cultural centres of Slovaks in Vojvodina. Slovak is one of the six official languages of the provincial administration in Vojvodina. The settlements in Vojvodina with absolute or relative Slovak majority are: * [[Bački Petrovac]] ([[Bački Petrovac]] municipality) * [[Kulpin, Serbia|Kulpin]] ([[Bački Petrovac]] municipality) * [[Gložan]] ([[Bački Petrovac]] municipality) * [[Kisač]] ([[Novi Sad]] municipality) * [[Pivnice]] ([[Bačka Palanka]] municipality) * [[Lalić]] ([[Odžaci]] municipality) * [[Selenča]] ([[Bač, Serbia|Bač]] municipality) * [[Lug (Beočin)|Lug]] ([[Beočin]] municipality) * [[Ljuba]] ([[Šid]] municipality) * [[Kovačica (town)|Kovačica]] ([[Kovačica (town)|Kovačica]] municipality) * [[Padina (Kovačica)|Padina]] ([[Kovačica (town)|Kovačica]] municipality) * [[Belo Blato]] ([[Zrenjanin]] municipality) * [[Hajdučica]] ([[Plandište]] municipality) * [[Janošik]] ([[Alibunar]] municipality) * [[Slankamenački Vinogradi]] ([[Inđija]] municipality) ==History== [[Image:Belo Blato, Catholic and Evangelical Churches.jpg|thumb|220px|The Catholic and the Evangelical Church in [[Belo Blato]]]] [[Image:Slovak-Traditional-Music-Festival-Glozan-Serbia.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Slovaks in Vojvodina]] [[File:Slovački dom u Šidu (Srbija) Slováci v Шиду.jpg|thumb|Slovak center in Šid.]] The modern Slovaks in Vojvodina are descendants of 18th- and 19th-century settlers, who migrated from the territory of present-day [[Slovakia]]. First Slovak settlers from area around [[Tatra Mountains|Tatra]] migrated to [[Bačka]] during the time of [[Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Karlo I]]; in 1720 Slovaks settled in [[Bajša]], in 1740 in [[Bački Petrovac|Petrovac]] and [[Futog]], and in 1742 (during the time of [[Maria Theresa of Austria|Maria Theresa]]) in [[Bezdan]]. Some of them also later moved to [[Syrmia|Srem]]. In 1760, 120 Slovak families were settled in [[Selenča]], but they later moved to [[Stara Pazova]] in Srem. In 1783, Slovaks settled in [[Kisač]], [[Kruščić|Veprovac]], [[Gložan]], and [[Bačka Topola|Topola]]. Part of them also settled in [[Bajša]]. In 1790-1791, Slovaks settled in [[Pivnice]], in 1792 in [[Stara Palanka]], and in 1793 in [[Novi Slankamen]]. In 1784-1787, Slovaks settled in [[Međa (Žitište)|Slovanski Bardan]]. In 1792 Slovaks settled in [[Bačka Palanka]]. Some of them moved in 1788 to [[Aradac]] and [[Ečka]], and some of them later also moved to [[Lalić]]. In 1800, Slovaks settled in [[Kovačica (town)|Kovačica]], and in 1806 and 1809 in [[Padina (Kovačica)|Padina]]. In 1806, one group of Slovaks settled in [[Čoka]], and in 1809 in [[Krajišnik, Serbia|Šupljaja]]. In 1825, Slovaks settled in [[Dušanovac, Banat|Dušanovac]], and in 1830 in [[Stari Lec]]. In 1850, 20 Slovak families were settled in [[Grk, Serbia|Grk]]. In 1868, Slovaks settled in [[Vojlovica, Pančevo|Marienfeld]], from where they later moved to [[Vojlovica, Pančevo|Vojlovica]]. In the same time, some Slovaks also settled in [[Ivanovo (Serbia)|Ivanovo]]. In 1887, Slovaks were settled in [[Belo Blato|Elizenhajm]], and in 1899 in [[Silađi]] colony near [[Apatin]]. According to the 1880 census, Slovaks were the sixth largest ethnic group within present-day Vojvodina, and their number was 43,318. Until the end of the [[First World War]], many of the Slovaks were [[Magyarization|Hungarized]]. According to the 2011 census, numbering 52,570, Slovaks are the sixth largest ethnic group in Serbia. ==Notable people== *[[Zorica Brunclik]], singer, by paternal descent *[[Gustav Maršal Petrovský]](''Gustav Maršal Petrovský''), writer *[[Ján Čajak]] (''Jan Čajak''), writer *[[Ján Čajak ml.]] (''Jan Čajak mlađi''), writer *[[Janko Čmelík]] (''Janko Čmelik''), [[Yugoslav Partisans|Partisan]] fighter and [[Order of the People's Hero|People's Hero of Yugoslavia]] *[[Zuzana Chalupová]] (''Zuzana Halupova''), naïve painter *[[Martin Jonáš]] (''Martin Jonaš''), naïve painter *[[Michal Kiráľ]] (''Mihal Kiralj''), academic painter *[[Ivan Križan]], painter *[[Zuzka Medveďová]] (''Zuska Medvedjova''), academic painter ==References== {{reflist}} * [[Borislav Jankulov]], ''Pregled kolonizacije Vojvodine u XVIII i XIX veku'', Novi Sad - Pančevo, 2003. == External links == * [http://www.vojvodinaslovakart.com Vojvodinian Slovaks contemporary and native art] {{sk icon}} {{sr icon}} {{en icon}} * [http://www.slovackizavod.org.rs/ Ústav pre kultúru vojvodinských Slovákov | slovackizavod.org.rs] {{sk icon}} {{sr icon}} {{en icon}} * [http://www.maticaslovenska.rs/ Matica slovenská v Srbsku] {{sk icon}} * [http://hl.rs/ Hlas Ľudu weekly magazine] {{sk icon}} {{Ethnic groups in Serbia}} {{Slovak diaspora}} [[Category:Slovak diaspora|Serbia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Serbia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Vojvodina]] [[Category:Serbian people of Slovak descent| ]]

{{SCCInfoBox |case-name=Trociuk v British Columbia (AG) |full-case-name=Darrell Wayne Trociuk v Attorney General of British Columbia, Director of Vital Statistics and Reni Ernst |heard-date=December 4, 2002 |decided-date=June 6, 2003 |citations=[2003] 1 SCR 835, 2003 SCC 34 |ruling= Appeal allowed. Sections 3(1)(b) and 3(6)(b) ''Vital Statistics Act'' are struck out. The declaration of invalidity suspended for 12 months. |SCC=2002-2003 |Unanimous=Deschamps J |LawsApplied=''[[Law v Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration)]]'', [1999] 1 SCR 497 }}{{italic title|all=yes|noerror}}'''''Trociuk v British Columbia (AG)''''', 2003 SCC 34 is a leading [[Supreme Court of Canada]] decision on [[Section Fifteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|section 15(1)]] of the ''[[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]]'' where a father successfully challenged a provision in the British Columbia ''Vital Statistics Act'' which gave a mother complete control over the identity of the father on a child's birth certificate on the basis it violated his equality rights.
==Background== Darrell Trociuk and Reni Ernst were an estranged unmarried couple who became parents to triplets in January 1996. When filling out the birth registration, Ernst had indicated the father was "unacknowledged by the mother" and that they were not together at the time. Consequently, she put "Ernst" as their surnames. However, Trociuk claimed they had agreed on registering the children's surnames as "Ernst-Trociuk" and tried to get the records changed to include his particulars.
Section 3(1)(b) and 4(1)(a) of the ''Vital Statistics Act'' prevented a father from amending registrations. Trociuk applied for a declaration to have the provision struck out as unconstitutional for violating his section 15 right to equality.
The Director of Vital Statistics denied the changing of the children's surnames to include their biological father's name. Trociuk then took his case to the [[British Columbia Supreme Court]], where it was upheld.
==Opinion of the court== Deschamps J, writing for a Supreme Court, allowed the appeal in favour of Trociuk. It was found that section 3 of the Act violated section 15(1) of the ''Charter'' by allowing differential treatment based on sex. The provision had the effect of excluding the father's particulars from birth registration, excluding him from choosing his child's surname, and precluding any recourse. These effects were found to be arbitrary and created significant impact on the perception of the father's dignity, and consequently violated section 15(1).
On the [[Section One of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|section 1]] analysis, Deschamps J held the violation could not be saved because the law did not impair Trociuk's rights as little as reasonably possible.
